trans-unit.source: Create a Web App in Azure App Service using the Azure SDK for Java
trans-unit.target: Create a Web App in Azure App Service using the Azure SDK for Java

trans-unit.source: Learn how to create a Web App on Azure App Service programmatically using the Azure SDK for Java.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to create a Web App on Azure App Service programmatically using the Azure SDK for Java.

trans-unit.source: Create a Web App in Azure App Service using the Azure SDK for Java
trans-unit.target: Create a Web App in Azure App Service using the Azure SDK for Java

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: This walkthrough shows you how to create an Azure SDK for Java application that creates a Web App in [Azure App Service][], then deploy an application to it.
trans-unit.target: This walkthrough shows you how to create an Azure SDK for Java application that creates a Web App in [Azure App Service][], then deploy an application to it.

trans-unit.source: It consists of two parts:
trans-unit.target: It consists of two parts:

trans-unit.source: Part 1 demonstrates how to build a Java application that creates a web app.
trans-unit.target: Part 1 demonstrates how to build a Java application that creates a web app.

trans-unit.source: Part 2 demonstrates how to create a simple JSP "Hello World" application, then use an FTP client to deploy code to App Service.
trans-unit.target: Part 2 demonstrates how to create a simple JSP "Hello World" application, then use an FTP client to deploy code to App Service.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: Software Installations
trans-unit.target: Software Installations

trans-unit.source: The AzureWebDemo application code in this article was written using Azure Java SDK 0.7.0, which you can install using the [Web Platform Installer][] (WebPI).
trans-unit.target: The AzureWebDemo application code in this article was written using Azure Java SDK 0.7.0, which you can install using the [Web Platform Installer][] (WebPI).

trans-unit.source: In addition, make sure to use the latest version of the [Azure Toolkit for Eclipse][].
trans-unit.target: In addition, make sure to use the latest version of the [Azure Toolkit for Eclipse][].

trans-unit.source: After you install the SDK, update the dependencies in your Eclipse project by running **Update Index** in **Maven Repositories**, then re-add the latest version of each package in the **Dependencies** window.
trans-unit.target: After you install the SDK, update the dependencies in your Eclipse project by running **Update Index** in **Maven Repositories**, then re-add the latest version of each package in the **Dependencies** window.

trans-unit.source: You can verify the version of your installed software in Eclipse by clicking **Help > Installation Details**; you should have at least the following versions:
trans-unit.target: You can verify the version of your installed software in Eclipse by clicking **Help > Installation Details**; you should have at least the following versions:

trans-unit.source: Package for Microsoft Azure Libraries for Java 0.7.0.20150309
trans-unit.target: Package for Microsoft Azure Libraries for Java 0.7.0.20150309

trans-unit.source: Eclipse IDE for Java EE Developers 4.4.2.20150219
trans-unit.target: Eclipse IDE for Java EE Developers 4.4.2.20150219

trans-unit.source: Create and Configure Cloud Resources in Azure
trans-unit.target: Create and Configure Cloud Resources in Azure

trans-unit.source: Before you begin this procedure, you need to have an active Azure subscription and set up a default Active Directory (AD) on Azure.
trans-unit.target: Before you begin this procedure, you need to have an active Azure subscription and set up a default Active Directory (AD) on Azure.

trans-unit.source: Create an Active Directory (AD) in Azure
trans-unit.target: Create an Active Directory (AD) in Azure

trans-unit.source: If you do not already have an Active Directory (AD) on your Azure subscription, log into the [Azure classic portal][] with your Microsoft account.
trans-unit.target: If you do not already have an Active Directory (AD) on your Azure subscription, log into the [Azure classic portal][] with your Microsoft account.

trans-unit.source: If you have multiple subscriptions, click **Subscriptions** and select the default directory for the subscription you want to use for this project.
trans-unit.target: If you have multiple subscriptions, click **Subscriptions** and select the default directory for the subscription you want to use for this project.

trans-unit.source: Then click **Apply** to switch to that subscription view.
trans-unit.target: Then click **Apply** to switch to that subscription view.

trans-unit.source: Select **Active Directory** from the menu at left.
trans-unit.target: Select **Active Directory** from the menu at left.

trans-unit.source: **Click New > Directory > Custom Create**.
trans-unit.target: **Click New > Directory > Custom Create**.

trans-unit.source: In **Add Directory**, select **Create New Directory**.
trans-unit.target: In **Add Directory**, select **Create New Directory**.

trans-unit.source: In **Name**, enter a directory name.
trans-unit.target: In **Name**, enter a directory name.

trans-unit.source: In **Domain**, enter a domain name.
trans-unit.target: In **Domain**, enter a domain name.

trans-unit.source: This is a basic domain name that is included by default with your directory; it has the form `<domain_name>.onmicrosoft.com`.
trans-unit.target: This is a basic domain name that is included by default with your directory; it has the form `<domain_name>.onmicrosoft.com`.

trans-unit.source: You can name it based on the directory name or another domain name that you own.
trans-unit.target: You can name it based on the directory name or another domain name that you own.

trans-unit.source: Later, you can add another domain name that your organization already uses.
trans-unit.target: Later, you can add another domain name that your organization already uses.

trans-unit.source: In **Country or region**, select your locale.
trans-unit.target: In **Country or region**, select your locale.

trans-unit.source: For more information on AD, see [What is an Azure AD directory][]?
trans-unit.target: For more information on AD, see [What is an Azure AD directory][]?

trans-unit.source: Create a Management Certificate for Azure
trans-unit.target: Create a Management Certificate for Azure

trans-unit.source: The Azure SDK for Java uses management certificates to authenticate with Azure subscriptions.
trans-unit.target: The Azure SDK for Java uses management certificates to authenticate with Azure subscriptions.

trans-unit.source: These are X.509 v3 certificates you use to authenticate a client application that uses the Service Management API to act on behalf of the subscription owner to manage subscription resources.
trans-unit.target: These are X.509 v3 certificates you use to authenticate a client application that uses the Service Management API to act on behalf of the subscription owner to manage subscription resources.

trans-unit.source: The code in this procedure uses a self-signed certificate to authenticate with Azure.
trans-unit.target: The code in this procedure uses a self-signed certificate to authenticate with Azure.

trans-unit.source: For this procedure, you need to create a certificate and upload it to the [Azure classic portal][] beforehand.
trans-unit.target: For this procedure, you need to create a certificate and upload it to the [Azure classic portal][] beforehand.

trans-unit.source: This involves the following steps:
trans-unit.target: This involves the following steps:

trans-unit.source: Generate a PFX file representing your client certificate and save it locally.
trans-unit.target: Generate a PFX file representing your client certificate and save it locally.

trans-unit.source: Generate a management certificate (CER file) from the PFX file.
trans-unit.target: Generate a management certificate (CER file) from the PFX file.

trans-unit.source: Upload the CER file to your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: Upload the CER file to your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: Convert the PFX file into JKS, because Java uses that format to authenticate using certificates.
trans-unit.target: Convert the PFX file into JKS, because Java uses that format to authenticate using certificates.

trans-unit.source: Write the application's authentication code, which refers to the local JKS file.
trans-unit.target: Write the application's authentication code, which refers to the local JKS file.

trans-unit.source: When you complete this procedure, the CER certificate will reside in your Azure subscription and the JKS certificate will reside on your local drive.
trans-unit.target: When you complete this procedure, the CER certificate will reside in your Azure subscription and the JKS certificate will reside on your local drive.

trans-unit.source: For more information on management certificates, see [Create and Upload a Management Certificate for Azure][].
trans-unit.target: For more information on management certificates, see [Create and Upload a Management Certificate for Azure][].

trans-unit.source: Create a certificate
trans-unit.target: Create a certificate

trans-unit.source: To create your own self-signed certificate, open a command console on your operating system and run the following commands.
trans-unit.target: To create your own self-signed certificate, open a command console on your operating system and run the following commands.

trans-unit.source: **Note:** The computer on which you run this command must have the JDK installed.
trans-unit.target: **Note:** The computer on which you run this command must have the JDK installed.

trans-unit.source: Also, the path to the keytool depends on the location in which you install the JDK.
trans-unit.target: Also, the path to the keytool depends on the location in which you install the JDK.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Key and Certificate Management Tool (keytool)][] in the Java online docs.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Key and Certificate Management Tool (keytool)][] in the Java online docs.

trans-unit.source: To create the .pfx file:
trans-unit.target: To create the .pfx file:

trans-unit.source: To create the .cer file:
trans-unit.target: To create the .cer file:

trans-unit.source: where:
trans-unit.target: where:

trans-unit.source: `<java-install-dir>` is the path to the directory in which you installed Java.
trans-unit.target: `<java-install-dir>` is the path to the directory in which you installed Java.

trans-unit.source: `<keystore-id>` is the keystore entry identifier (for example, `AzureRemoteAccess`).
trans-unit.target: `<keystore-id>` is the keystore entry identifier (for example, `AzureRemoteAccess`).

trans-unit.source: `<cert-store-dir>` is the path to the directory in which you want to store certificates (for example `C:/Certificates`).
trans-unit.target: `<cert-store-dir>` is the path to the directory in which you want to store certificates (for example `C:/Certificates`).

trans-unit.source: `<cert-file-name>` is the name of the certificate file (for example `AzureWebDemoCert`).
trans-unit.target: `<cert-file-name>` is the name of the certificate file (for example `AzureWebDemoCert`).

trans-unit.source: `<password>` is the password you choose to protect the certificate; it must be at least 6 characters long.
trans-unit.target: `<password>` is the password you choose to protect the certificate; it must be at least 6 characters long.

trans-unit.source: You can enter no password, although this is not recommended.
trans-unit.target: You can enter no password, although this is not recommended.

trans-unit.source: `<dname>` is the X.500 Distinguished Name to be associated with alias, and is used as the issuer and subject fields in the self-signed certificate.
trans-unit.target: `<dname>` is the X.500 Distinguished Name to be associated with alias, and is used as the issuer and subject fields in the self-signed certificate.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Create and Upload a Management Certificate for Azure][].
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Create and Upload a Management Certificate for Azure][].

trans-unit.source: Upload the certificate
trans-unit.target: Upload the certificate

trans-unit.source: To upload a self-signed certificate to Azure, go to the **Settings** page in the classic portal, then click the **Management Certificates** tab.
trans-unit.target: To upload a self-signed certificate to Azure, go to the **Settings** page in the classic portal, then click the **Management Certificates** tab.

trans-unit.source: Click **Upload** at the bottom of the page and navigate to the location of the CER file you created.
trans-unit.target: Click **Upload** at the bottom of the page and navigate to the location of the CER file you created.

trans-unit.source: Convert the PFX file into JKS
trans-unit.target: Convert the PFX file into JKS

trans-unit.source: In the Windows Command Prompt (running as admin), cd to the directory containing the certificates and run the following command, where `<java-install-dir>` is the directory in which you installed Java on your computer:
trans-unit.target: In the Windows Command Prompt (running as admin), cd to the directory containing the certificates and run the following command, where `<java-install-dir>` is the directory in which you installed Java on your computer:

trans-unit.source: When prompted, enter the destination keystore password; this will be the password for the JKS file.
trans-unit.target: When prompted, enter the destination keystore password; this will be the password for the JKS file.

trans-unit.source: When prompted, enter the source keystore password; this is the password you specified for the PFX file.
trans-unit.target: When prompted, enter the source keystore password; this is the password you specified for the PFX file.

trans-unit.source: The two passwords do not have to be the same.
trans-unit.target: The two passwords do not have to be the same.

trans-unit.source: You can enter no password, although this is not recommended.
trans-unit.target: You can enter no password, although this is not recommended.

trans-unit.source: Build a Web App creation application
trans-unit.target: Build a Web App creation application

trans-unit.source: Create the Eclipse Workspace and Maven Project
trans-unit.target: Create the Eclipse Workspace and Maven Project

trans-unit.source: In this section you create a workspace and a Maven project for the web app creation application, named AzureWebDemo.
trans-unit.target: In this section you create a workspace and a Maven project for the web app creation application, named AzureWebDemo.

trans-unit.source: Create a new Maven project.
trans-unit.target: Create a new Maven project.

trans-unit.source: Click **File > New > Maven Project**.
trans-unit.target: Click **File > New > Maven Project**.

trans-unit.source: In **New Maven Project**, select **Create a simple project** and **Use default workspace location**.
trans-unit.target: In **New Maven Project**, select **Create a simple project** and **Use default workspace location**.

trans-unit.source: On the second page of **New Maven Project**, specify the following:
trans-unit.target: On the second page of **New Maven Project**, specify the following:

trans-unit.source: Group ID: `com.<username>.azure.webdemo`
trans-unit.target: Group ID: `com.<username>.azure.webdemo`

trans-unit.source: Artifact ID: AzureWebDemo
trans-unit.target: Artifact ID: AzureWebDemo

trans-unit.source: Version: 0.0.1-SNAPSHOT
trans-unit.target: Version: 0.0.1-SNAPSHOT

trans-unit.source: Packaging: jar
trans-unit.target: Packaging: jar

trans-unit.source: Name: AzureWebDemo
trans-unit.target: Name: AzureWebDemo

trans-unit.source: Click **Finish**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Finish**.

trans-unit.source: Open the new project's pom.xml file in Project Explorer.
trans-unit.target: Open the new project's pom.xml file in Project Explorer.

trans-unit.source: Select the **Dependencies** tab.
trans-unit.target: Select the **Dependencies** tab.

trans-unit.source: As this is a new project, no packages are listed yet.
trans-unit.target: As this is a new project, no packages are listed yet.

trans-unit.source: Open the Maven Repositories view.
trans-unit.target: Open the Maven Repositories view.

trans-unit.source: **Click Window > Show View > Other > Maven > Maven Repositories** and click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: **Click Window > Show View > Other > Maven > Maven Repositories** and click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: The **Maven Repositories** view will appear at the bottom of the IDE.
trans-unit.target: The **Maven Repositories** view will appear at the bottom of the IDE.

trans-unit.source: Open **Global Repositories**, right-click the **central** repository, and select **Rebuild Index**.
trans-unit.target: Open **Global Repositories**, right-click the **central** repository, and select **Rebuild Index**.

trans-unit.source: This step can take several minutes depending on the speed of your connection.
trans-unit.target: This step can take several minutes depending on the speed of your connection.

trans-unit.source: When the index rebuilds, you should see the Microsoft Azure packages in the **central** Maven repository.
trans-unit.target: When the index rebuilds, you should see the Microsoft Azure packages in the **central** Maven repository.

trans-unit.source: In **Dependencies**, click **Add**.
trans-unit.target: In **Dependencies**, click **Add**.

trans-unit.source: In **Enter Group ID...** enter `azure-management`.
trans-unit.target: In **Enter Group ID...** enter `azure-management`.

trans-unit.source: Select the packages for base management and App Service Web Apps management:
trans-unit.target: Select the packages for base management and App Service Web Apps management:

trans-unit.source: **Note:** If you are updating the dependencies after a new version
trans-unit.target: **Note:** If you are updating the dependencies after a new version

trans-unit.source: release, you need to re-add each of the dependencies in this list.
trans-unit.target: release, you need to re-add each of the dependencies in this list.

trans-unit.source: After you click **Add** and select each dependency, it appears
trans-unit.target: After you click **Add** and select each dependency, it appears

trans-unit.source: with the new version number in the **Dependencies** list.
trans-unit.target: with the new version number in the **Dependencies** list.

trans-unit.source: Click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: Click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: The Azure packages then appear in the **Dependencies** list.
trans-unit.target: The Azure packages then appear in the **Dependencies** list.

trans-unit.source: Writing Java Code to Create a Web App by Calling the Azure SDK
trans-unit.target: Writing Java Code to Create a Web App by Calling the Azure SDK

trans-unit.source: Next, write the code that calls APIs in the Azure SDK for Java to create the App Service web app.
trans-unit.target: Next, write the code that calls APIs in the Azure SDK for Java to create the App Service web app.

trans-unit.source: Create a Java class to contain the main entry point code.
trans-unit.target: Create a Java class to contain the main entry point code.

trans-unit.source: In Project Explorer, right-click on the project node and select **New > Class**.
trans-unit.target: In Project Explorer, right-click on the project node and select **New > Class**.

trans-unit.source: In **New Java Class**, name the class `WebCreator` and check the **public static void main** checkbox.
trans-unit.target: In **New Java Class**, name the class `WebCreator` and check the **public static void main** checkbox.

trans-unit.source: The selections should appear as follows:
trans-unit.target: The selections should appear as follows:

trans-unit.source: Click **Finish**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Finish**.

trans-unit.source: The WebCreator.java file appears in Project Explorer.
trans-unit.target: The WebCreator.java file appears in Project Explorer.

trans-unit.source: Calling the Azure API to Create an App Service Web App
trans-unit.target: Calling the Azure API to Create an App Service Web App

trans-unit.source: Add necessary imports
trans-unit.target: Add necessary imports

trans-unit.source: In WebCreator.java, add the following imports; these imports provide access to classes in the management libraries for consuming Azure APIs:
trans-unit.target: In WebCreator.java, add the following imports; these imports provide access to classes in the management libraries for consuming Azure APIs:

trans-unit.source: Define the main entry point class
trans-unit.target: Define the main entry point class

trans-unit.source: Because the purpose of the AzureWebDemo application is to create an App Service Web App, name the main class for this application `WebAppCreator`.
trans-unit.target: Because the purpose of the AzureWebDemo application is to create an App Service Web App, name the main class for this application `WebAppCreator`.

trans-unit.source: This class provides the main entry point code that calls the Azure Service Management API to create the web app.
trans-unit.target: This class provides the main entry point code that calls the Azure Service Management API to create the web app.

trans-unit.source: Add the following parameter definitions for the web app and webspace.
trans-unit.target: Add the following parameter definitions for the web app and webspace.

trans-unit.source: You will need to provide your own Azure subscription ID and certificate information.
trans-unit.target: You will need to provide your own Azure subscription ID and certificate information.

trans-unit.source: where:
trans-unit.target: where:

trans-unit.source: `<subscription-id>` is the Azure subscription ID in which you want to create the resource.
trans-unit.target: `<subscription-id>` is the Azure subscription ID in which you want to create the resource.

trans-unit.source: `<certificate-store-path>` is the path and filename to the JKS file in your local certificate store directory.
trans-unit.target: `<certificate-store-path>` is the path and filename to the JKS file in your local certificate store directory.

trans-unit.source: For example, `C:/Certificates/CertificateName.jks` for Linux and `C:\Certificates\CertificateName.jks` for Windows.
trans-unit.target: For example, `C:/Certificates/CertificateName.jks` for Linux and `C:\Certificates\CertificateName.jks` for Windows.

trans-unit.source: `<certificate-password>` is the password you specified when you created your JKS certificate.
trans-unit.target: `<certificate-password>` is the password you specified when you created your JKS certificate.

trans-unit.source: `webAppName` can be any name you choose; this procedure uses the name `WebDemoWebApp`.
trans-unit.target: `webAppName` can be any name you choose; this procedure uses the name `WebDemoWebApp`.

trans-unit.source: The full domain name is the `webAppName` with the `domainName` appended, so in this case the full domain is `webdemowebapp.azurewebsites.net`.
trans-unit.target: The full domain name is the `webAppName` with the `domainName` appended, so in this case the full domain is `webdemowebapp.azurewebsites.net`.

trans-unit.source: `domainName` should be specified as shown above.
trans-unit.target: `domainName` should be specified as shown above.

trans-unit.source: `webSpaceName` should be one of the values defined in the [WebSpaceNames][] class.
trans-unit.target: `webSpaceName` should be one of the values defined in the [WebSpaceNames][] class.

trans-unit.source: `appServicePlanName` should be specified as shown above.
trans-unit.target: `appServicePlanName` should be specified as shown above.

trans-unit.source: **Note:** Each time you run this application, you need to change the value
trans-unit.target: **Note:** Each time you run this application, you need to change the value

trans-unit.source: of `webAppName` and `appServicePlanName` (or delete the web app on the Azure
trans-unit.target: of `webAppName` and `appServicePlanName` (or delete the web app on the Azure

trans-unit.source: Portal) before running the application again.
trans-unit.target: Portal) before running the application again.

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, execution will
trans-unit.target: Otherwise, execution will

trans-unit.source: fail because the same resource already exists on Azure.
trans-unit.target: fail because the same resource already exists on Azure.

trans-unit.source: Define the web creation method
trans-unit.target: Define the web creation method

trans-unit.source: Next, define a method to create the web app.
trans-unit.target: Next, define a method to create the web app.

trans-unit.source: This method, `createWebApp`, specifies the parameters of the web app and the webspace.
trans-unit.target: This method, `createWebApp`, specifies the parameters of the web app and the webspace.

trans-unit.source: It also creates and configures the App Service Web Apps management client, which is defined by the [WebSiteManagementClient][] object.
trans-unit.target: It also creates and configures the App Service Web Apps management client, which is defined by the [WebSiteManagementClient][] object.

trans-unit.source: The management client is key to creating Web Apps.
trans-unit.target: The management client is key to creating Web Apps.

trans-unit.source: It provides RESTful web services that allow applications to manage web apps (performing operations such as create, update, and delete) by calling the service management API.
trans-unit.target: It provides RESTful web services that allow applications to manage web apps (performing operations such as create, update, and delete) by calling the service management API.

trans-unit.source: The code will output the HTTP status of the response indicating success or failure, and if successful, will output the name of the created web app.
trans-unit.target: The code will output the HTTP status of the response indicating success or failure, and if successful, will output the name of the created web app.

trans-unit.source: Define the main() method
trans-unit.target: Define the main() method

trans-unit.source: Provide the main() method code that calls createWebApp() to create the web app.
trans-unit.target: Provide the main() method code that calls createWebApp() to create the web app.

trans-unit.source: Finally, call `createWebApp` from `main`:
trans-unit.target: Finally, call `createWebApp` from `main`:

trans-unit.source: Run the application and verify web app creation
trans-unit.target: Run the application and verify web app creation

trans-unit.source: To verify that your application runs, click **Run > Run**.
trans-unit.target: To verify that your application runs, click **Run > Run**.

trans-unit.source: When the application completes running, you should see the following output in the Eclipse console:
trans-unit.target: When the application completes running, you should see the following output in the Eclipse console:

trans-unit.source: Log into the Azure classic portal and click **Web Apps**.
trans-unit.target: Log into the Azure classic portal and click **Web Apps**.

trans-unit.source: The new web app should appear in the Web Apps list within a few minutes.
trans-unit.target: The new web app should appear in the Web Apps list within a few minutes.

trans-unit.source: Deploying an Application to the Web App
trans-unit.target: Deploying an Application to the Web App

trans-unit.source: After you have run AzureWebDemo and created the new web app, log into the classic portal, click **Web Apps**, and select **WebDemoWebApp** in the **Web Apps** list.
trans-unit.target: After you have run AzureWebDemo and created the new web app, log into the classic portal, click **Web Apps**, and select **WebDemoWebApp** in the **Web Apps** list.

trans-unit.source: In the web app's dashboard page, click **Browse** (or click the URL, `webdemowebapp.azurewebsites.net`) to navigate to it.
trans-unit.target: In the web app's dashboard page, click **Browse** (or click the URL, `webdemowebapp.azurewebsites.net`) to navigate to it.

trans-unit.source: You will see a blank placeholder page, because no content has been published to the web app yet.
trans-unit.target: You will see a blank placeholder page, because no content has been published to the web app yet.

trans-unit.source: Next you will create a "Hello World" application and deploy it to the web app.
trans-unit.target: Next you will create a "Hello World" application and deploy it to the web app.

trans-unit.source: Create a JSP Hello World application
trans-unit.target: Create a JSP Hello World application

trans-unit.source: Create the application
trans-unit.target: Create the application

trans-unit.source: In order to demonstrate how to deploy an application to the web, the following procedure shows you how to create a simple "Hello World" Java application and upload it to the App Service Web App that your application created.
trans-unit.target: In order to demonstrate how to deploy an application to the web, the following procedure shows you how to create a simple "Hello World" Java application and upload it to the App Service Web App that your application created.

trans-unit.source: Click **File > New > Dynamic Web Project**.
trans-unit.target: Click **File > New > Dynamic Web Project**.

trans-unit.source: Name it `JSPHello`.
trans-unit.target: Name it `JSPHello`.

trans-unit.source: You do not need to change any other settings in this dialog.
trans-unit.target: You do not need to change any other settings in this dialog.

trans-unit.source: Click **Finish**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Finish**.

trans-unit.source: In Project Explorer, expand the **JSPHello** project, right-click **WebContent**, then click **New > JSP File**.
trans-unit.target: In Project Explorer, expand the **JSPHello** project, right-click **WebContent**, then click **New > JSP File**.

trans-unit.source: In the New JSP File dialog, name the new file `index.jsp`.
trans-unit.target: In the New JSP File dialog, name the new file `index.jsp`.

trans-unit.source: Click **Next**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Next**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Select JSP Template** dialog, select **New JSP File (html)** and click **Finish**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Select JSP Template** dialog, select **New JSP File (html)** and click **Finish**.

trans-unit.source: In index.jsp, add the following code in the `<head>` and `<body>` tag sections:
trans-unit.target: In index.jsp, add the following code in the `<head>` and `<body>` tag sections:

trans-unit.source: Run the Hello World application in localhost
trans-unit.target: Run the Hello World application in localhost

trans-unit.source: Before you run this application, you need to configure a few properties.
trans-unit.target: Before you run this application, you need to configure a few properties.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the **JSPHello** project and select **Properties**.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the **JSPHello** project and select **Properties**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Properties** dialog: select **Java Build Path**, select the **Order and Export** tab, check **JRE System Library**, then click **Up** to move it to the top of the list.
trans-unit.target: In the **Properties** dialog: select **Java Build Path**, select the **Order and Export** tab, check **JRE System Library**, then click **Up** to move it to the top of the list.

trans-unit.source: Also in the **Properties** dialog: select **Targeted Runtimes** and click **New**.
trans-unit.target: Also in the **Properties** dialog: select **Targeted Runtimes** and click **New**.

trans-unit.source: In the **New Server Runtime Environment** dialog, select a server such as **Apache Tomcat v7.0** and click **Next**.
trans-unit.target: In the **New Server Runtime Environment** dialog, select a server such as **Apache Tomcat v7.0** and click **Next**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Tomcat Server** dialog, set **Name** to `Apache Tomcat v7.0`, and set **Tomcat Installation Directory** to the directory in which you installed the version of Tomcat server you want to use.
trans-unit.target: In the **Tomcat Server** dialog, set **Name** to `Apache Tomcat v7.0`, and set **Tomcat Installation Directory** to the directory in which you installed the version of Tomcat server you want to use.

trans-unit.source: Click **Finish**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Finish**.

trans-unit.source: You then return to the **Targeted Runtimes** page of the **Properties** dialog.
trans-unit.target: You then return to the **Targeted Runtimes** page of the **Properties** dialog.

trans-unit.source: Select **Apache Tomcat v7.0**, then click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: Select **Apache Tomcat v7.0**, then click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: In the Eclipse **Run** menu, click **Run**.
trans-unit.target: In the Eclipse **Run** menu, click **Run**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Run As** dialog, select **Run on Server**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Run As** dialog, select **Run on Server**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Run on Server** dialog, select **Tomcat v7.0 Server**:
trans-unit.target: In the **Run on Server** dialog, select **Tomcat v7.0 Server**:

trans-unit.source: Click **Finish**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Finish**.

trans-unit.source: When the application runs, you should see the **JSPHello** page appear in a localhost window in Eclipse (`http://localhost:8080/JSPHello/`), displaying the following message:
trans-unit.target: When the application runs, you should see the **JSPHello** page appear in a localhost window in Eclipse (`http://localhost:8080/JSPHello/`), displaying the following message:

trans-unit.source: Export the application as a WAR
trans-unit.target: Export the application as a WAR

trans-unit.source: Export the web project files as a web archive (WAR) file so that you can deploy it to the web app.
trans-unit.target: Export the web project files as a web archive (WAR) file so that you can deploy it to the web app.

trans-unit.source: The following web project files reside in the WebContent folder:
trans-unit.target: The following web project files reside in the WebContent folder:

trans-unit.source: Right-click the WebContent folder and select **Export**.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the WebContent folder and select **Export**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Export Select** dialog, click **Web > WAR** file, then click **Next**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Export Select** dialog, click **Web > WAR** file, then click **Next**.

trans-unit.source: In the **WAR Export** dialog, select the src directory in the current project, and include the name of the WAR file at the end.
trans-unit.target: In the **WAR Export** dialog, select the src directory in the current project, and include the name of the WAR file at the end.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: For more information on deploying WAR files, see [Add a Java application to Azure App Service Web Apps](web-sites-java-add-app.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information on deploying WAR files, see [Add a Java application to Azure App Service Web Apps](web-sites-java-add-app.md).

trans-unit.source: Deploying the Hello World Application Using FTP
trans-unit.target: Deploying the Hello World Application Using FTP

trans-unit.source: Select a third-party FTP client to publish the application.
trans-unit.target: Select a third-party FTP client to publish the application.

trans-unit.source: This procedure describes two options: the Kudu console built into Azure; and FileZilla, a popular tool with a convenient, graphical UI.
trans-unit.target: This procedure describes two options: the Kudu console built into Azure; and FileZilla, a popular tool with a convenient, graphical UI.

trans-unit.source: **Note:** The Azure Plugin for Eclipse with Java 2.4 supports deployment to storage accounts and cloud services, but does not currently support deployment to web apps.
trans-unit.target: **Note:** The Azure Plugin for Eclipse with Java 2.4 supports deployment to storage accounts and cloud services, but does not currently support deployment to web apps.

trans-unit.source: You can deploy to storage accounts and cloud services using an Azure Deployment Project as described in [Creating a Hello World Application for Azure in Eclipse](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/hh690944.aspx), but not to web apps.
trans-unit.target: You can deploy to storage accounts and cloud services using an Azure Deployment Project as described in [Creating a Hello World Application for Azure in Eclipse](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/hh690944.aspx), but not to web apps.

trans-unit.source: Use other methods such as FTP or GitHub to transfer files to your web app.
trans-unit.target: Use other methods such as FTP or GitHub to transfer files to your web app.

trans-unit.source: **Note:** We do not recommend using FTP from the Windows command prompt (the command-line FTP.EXE utility that ships with Windows).
trans-unit.target: **Note:** We do not recommend using FTP from the Windows command prompt (the command-line FTP.EXE utility that ships with Windows).

trans-unit.source: FTP clients that use active FTP, such as FTP.EXE, often fail to work over firewalls.
trans-unit.target: FTP clients that use active FTP, such as FTP.EXE, often fail to work over firewalls.

trans-unit.source: Active FTP specifies an internal LAN-based address, to which an FTP server will likely fail to connect.
trans-unit.target: Active FTP specifies an internal LAN-based address, to which an FTP server will likely fail to connect.

trans-unit.source: For more information on deployment to an App Service web app using FTP, see the following topics:
trans-unit.target: For more information on deployment to an App Service web app using FTP, see the following topics:

trans-unit.source: Deploy using an FTP utility
trans-unit.target: Deploy using an FTP utility

trans-unit.source: Set up deployment credentials
trans-unit.target: Set up deployment credentials

trans-unit.source: Make sure you have run the **AzureWebDemo** application to create a web app.
trans-unit.target: Make sure you have run the **AzureWebDemo** application to create a web app.

trans-unit.source: You will transfer files to this location.
trans-unit.target: You will transfer files to this location.

trans-unit.source: Log into the classic portal and click **Web Apps**.
trans-unit.target: Log into the classic portal and click **Web Apps**.

trans-unit.source: Make sure **WebDemoWebApp** appears in the list of web apps, and make sure that it is running.
trans-unit.target: Make sure **WebDemoWebApp** appears in the list of web apps, and make sure that it is running.

trans-unit.source: Click **WebDemoWebApp** to open its **Dashboard** page.
trans-unit.target: Click **WebDemoWebApp** to open its **Dashboard** page.

trans-unit.source: On the **Dashboard** page, under **Quick Glance**, click **Set up your deployment credentials** (if you already have deployment credentials, this reads **Reset your deployment credentials**).
trans-unit.target: On the **Dashboard** page, under **Quick Glance**, click **Set up your deployment credentials** (if you already have deployment credentials, this reads **Reset your deployment credentials**).

trans-unit.source: Deployment credentials are associated with a Microsoft account.
trans-unit.target: Deployment credentials are associated with a Microsoft account.

trans-unit.source: You need to specify a username and password that you can use to deploy using Git and FTP.
trans-unit.target: You need to specify a username and password that you can use to deploy using Git and FTP.

trans-unit.source: You can use these credentials to deploy to any web app in all Azure subscriptions associated with your Microsoft account.
trans-unit.target: You can use these credentials to deploy to any web app in all Azure subscriptions associated with your Microsoft account.

trans-unit.source: Provide Git and FTP deployment credentials in the dialog, and record the username and password for future use.
trans-unit.target: Provide Git and FTP deployment credentials in the dialog, and record the username and password for future use.

trans-unit.source: Get FTP connection information
trans-unit.target: Get FTP connection information

trans-unit.source: To use FTP to deploy application files to the newly created web app, you need to obtain connection information.
trans-unit.target: To use FTP to deploy application files to the newly created web app, you need to obtain connection information.

trans-unit.source: There are two ways to obtain connection information.
trans-unit.target: There are two ways to obtain connection information.

trans-unit.source: One way is to visit the web app's **Dashboard** page; the other way is to download the web app's publish profile.
trans-unit.target: One way is to visit the web app's **Dashboard** page; the other way is to download the web app's publish profile.

trans-unit.source: The publish profile is an XML file that provides information such as FTP host name and logon credentials for your web apps in Azure App Service.
trans-unit.target: The publish profile is an XML file that provides information such as FTP host name and logon credentials for your web apps in Azure App Service.

trans-unit.source: You can use this username and password to deploy to any web app in all subscriptions associated with the Azure account, not only this one.
trans-unit.target: You can use this username and password to deploy to any web app in all subscriptions associated with the Azure account, not only this one.

trans-unit.source: To obtain FTP connection information from the web app's blade in the [Azure Portal][]:
trans-unit.target: To obtain FTP connection information from the web app's blade in the [Azure Portal][]:

trans-unit.source: Under **Essentials**, find and copy the **FTP hostname**.
trans-unit.target: Under **Essentials**, find and copy the **FTP hostname**.

trans-unit.source: This is a URI similar to `ftp://waws-prod-bay-NNN.ftp.azurewebsites.windows.net`.
trans-unit.target: This is a URI similar to `ftp://waws-prod-bay-NNN.ftp.azurewebsites.windows.net`.

trans-unit.source: Under **Essentials**, find and copy **FTP/Deployment username**.
trans-unit.target: Under **Essentials**, find and copy **FTP/Deployment username**.

trans-unit.source: This will have the form *webappname\deployment-username*; for example `WebDemoWebApp\deployer77`.
trans-unit.target: This will have the form *webappname\deployment-username*; for example `WebDemoWebApp\deployer77`.

trans-unit.source: To obtain FTP connection information from the publish profile:
trans-unit.target: To obtain FTP connection information from the publish profile:

trans-unit.source: In the web app's blade, click **Get publish profile**.
trans-unit.target: In the web app's blade, click **Get publish profile**.

trans-unit.source: This will download a .publishsettings file to your local drive.
trans-unit.target: This will download a .publishsettings file to your local drive.

trans-unit.source: Open the .publishsettings file in an XML editor or text editor and find the `<publishProfile>` element containing `publishMethod="FTP"`.
trans-unit.target: Open the .publishsettings file in an XML editor or text editor and find the `<publishProfile>` element containing `publishMethod="FTP"`.

trans-unit.source: It should look like the following:
trans-unit.target: It should look like the following:

trans-unit.source: Note that the web app's `publishProfile` settings map to the FileZilla Site Manager settings as follows:
trans-unit.target: Note that the web app's `publishProfile` settings map to the FileZilla Site Manager settings as follows:

trans-unit.source: `publishUrl` is the same as **FTP host name**, the value you set in **Host**.
trans-unit.target: `publishUrl` is the same as **FTP host name**, the value you set in **Host**.

trans-unit.source: `publishMethod="FTP"` means that you set **Protocol** to **FTP - File Transfer Protocol**, and **Encryption** to **Use plain FTP**.
trans-unit.target: `publishMethod="FTP"` means that you set **Protocol** to **FTP - File Transfer Protocol**, and **Encryption** to **Use plain FTP**.

trans-unit.source: `userName` and `userPWD` are keys for the actual username and password values you specified when you reset the deployment credentials.
trans-unit.target: `userName` and `userPWD` are keys for the actual username and password values you specified when you reset the deployment credentials.

trans-unit.source: `userName` is the same as **Deployment / FTP user**.
trans-unit.target: `userName` is the same as **Deployment / FTP user**.

trans-unit.source: They map to **User** and **Password** in FileZilla.
trans-unit.target: They map to **User** and **Password** in FileZilla.

trans-unit.source: `ftpPassiveMode="True"` means that the FTP site uses passive FTP transfer; select **Passive** on the **Transfer Settings** tab.
trans-unit.target: `ftpPassiveMode="True"` means that the FTP site uses passive FTP transfer; select **Passive** on the **Transfer Settings** tab.

trans-unit.source: Configure the Web App to host a Java application
trans-unit.target: Configure the Web App to host a Java application

trans-unit.source: Before you publish the application, you need to change a few configuration settings so that the web app can host a Java application.
trans-unit.target: Before you publish the application, you need to change a few configuration settings so that the web app can host a Java application.

trans-unit.source: In the classic portal, go to the web app's **Dashboard** page and click **Configure**.
trans-unit.target: In the classic portal, go to the web app's **Dashboard** page and click **Configure**.

trans-unit.source: On the **Configure** page, specify the following settings.
trans-unit.target: On the **Configure** page, specify the following settings.

trans-unit.source: In **Java version** the default is **Off**; select the Java version your application targets; for example 1.7.0_51.
trans-unit.target: In **Java version** the default is **Off**; select the Java version your application targets; for example 1.7.0_51.

trans-unit.source: After you do this, also make sure that **Web container** is set to a version of Tomcat Server.
trans-unit.target: After you do this, also make sure that **Web container** is set to a version of Tomcat Server.

trans-unit.source: In **Default Documents**, add index.jsp and move it up to the top of the list.
trans-unit.target: In **Default Documents**, add index.jsp and move it up to the top of the list.

trans-unit.source: (The default file for web apps is hostingstart.html.)
trans-unit.target: (The default file for web apps is hostingstart.html.)

trans-unit.source: Click **Save**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Save**.

trans-unit.source: Publish your application using Kudu
trans-unit.target: Publish your application using Kudu

trans-unit.source: One way to publish the application is to use the Kudu debug console built into Azure.
trans-unit.target: One way to publish the application is to use the Kudu debug console built into Azure.

trans-unit.source: Kudu is known to be stable and consistent with App Service Web Apps and Tomcat Server.
trans-unit.target: Kudu is known to be stable and consistent with App Service Web Apps and Tomcat Server.

trans-unit.source: You access the console for the web app by browsing to a URL of the following form:
trans-unit.target: You access the console for the web app by browsing to a URL of the following form:

trans-unit.source: For this procedure, the Kudu console is located at the following URL; browse to this location:
trans-unit.target: For this procedure, the Kudu console is located at the following URL; browse to this location:

trans-unit.source: From the top menu, select **Debug Console > CMD**.
trans-unit.target: From the top menu, select **Debug Console > CMD**.

trans-unit.source: In the console command line, navigate to `/site/wwwroot` (or click `site`, then `wwwroot` in the directory view at the top of the page):
trans-unit.target: In the console command line, navigate to `/site/wwwroot` (or click `site`, then `wwwroot` in the directory view at the top of the page):

trans-unit.source: After you specify **Java version**, Tomcat server should create a webapps directory.
trans-unit.target: After you specify **Java version**, Tomcat server should create a webapps directory.

trans-unit.source: In the console command line, navigate to the webapps directory:
trans-unit.target: In the console command line, navigate to the webapps directory:

trans-unit.source: Drag JSPHello.war from `<project-path>/JSPHello/src/` and drop it into the Kudu directory view under `/site/wwwroot/webapps`.
trans-unit.target: Drag JSPHello.war from `<project-path>/JSPHello/src/` and drop it into the Kudu directory view under `/site/wwwroot/webapps`.

trans-unit.source: Do not drag it to the "Drag here to upload and zip" area, because Tomcat will unzip it.
trans-unit.target: Do not drag it to the "Drag here to upload and zip" area, because Tomcat will unzip it.

trans-unit.source: At first JSPHello.war appears in the directory area by itself:
trans-unit.target: At first JSPHello.war appears in the directory area by itself:

trans-unit.source: In a short time (probably less than 5 minutes) Tomcat Server will unzip the WAR file into an unpacked JSPHello directory.
trans-unit.target: In a short time (probably less than 5 minutes) Tomcat Server will unzip the WAR file into an unpacked JSPHello directory.

trans-unit.source: Click the ROOT directory to see whether index.jsp has been unzipped and copied there.
trans-unit.target: Click the ROOT directory to see whether index.jsp has been unzipped and copied there.

trans-unit.source: If so, navigate back to the webapps directory to see whether the unpacked JSPHello directory has been created.
trans-unit.target: If so, navigate back to the webapps directory to see whether the unpacked JSPHello directory has been created.

trans-unit.source: If you do not see these items, wait and repeat.
trans-unit.target: If you do not see these items, wait and repeat.

trans-unit.source: Publish your application using FileZilla (optional)
trans-unit.target: Publish your application using FileZilla (optional)

trans-unit.source: Another tool you can use to publish the application is FileZilla, a popular third-party FTP client with a convenient, graphical UI.
trans-unit.target: Another tool you can use to publish the application is FileZilla, a popular third-party FTP client with a convenient, graphical UI.

trans-unit.source: You can download and install FileZilla from [http://filezilla-project.org/](http://filezilla-project.org/) if you do not already have it.
trans-unit.target: You can download and install FileZilla from [http://filezilla-project.org/](http://filezilla-project.org/) if you do not already have it.

trans-unit.source: For more information on using the client, see the [FileZilla documentation](https://wiki.filezilla-project.org/Documentation) and this blog entry on [FTP Clients - Part 4: FileZilla](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/robert_mcmurray/archive/2008/12/17/ftp-clients-part-4-filezilla.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information on using the client, see the [FileZilla documentation](https://wiki.filezilla-project.org/Documentation) and this blog entry on [FTP Clients - Part 4: FileZilla](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/robert_mcmurray/archive/2008/12/17/ftp-clients-part-4-filezilla.aspx).

trans-unit.source: In FileZilla, click **File > Site Manager**.
trans-unit.target: In FileZilla, click **File > Site Manager**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Site Manager** dialog, click **New Site**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Site Manager** dialog, click **New Site**.

trans-unit.source: A new blank FTP site will appear in **Select Entry** prompting you to provide a name.
trans-unit.target: A new blank FTP site will appear in **Select Entry** prompting you to provide a name.

trans-unit.source: For this procedure, name it `AzureWebDemo-FTP`.
trans-unit.target: For this procedure, name it `AzureWebDemo-FTP`.

trans-unit.source: On the **General** tab, specify the following settings:
trans-unit.target: On the **General** tab, specify the following settings:

trans-unit.source: **Host:** Enter the **FTP Host Name** that you copied from the dashboard.
trans-unit.target: **Host:** Enter the **FTP Host Name** that you copied from the dashboard.

trans-unit.source: **Port:** (Leave this blank, as this is a passive transfer and the server will determine the port to use.)
trans-unit.target: **Port:** (Leave this blank, as this is a passive transfer and the server will determine the port to use.)

trans-unit.source: **Protocol:** FTP File Transfer Protocol
trans-unit.target: **Protocol:** FTP File Transfer Protocol

trans-unit.source: **Encryption:** Use plain FTP
trans-unit.target: **Encryption:** Use plain FTP

trans-unit.source: **Logon Type:** Normal
trans-unit.target: **Logon Type:** Normal

trans-unit.source: **User:** Enter the Deployment / FTP user that you copied from the dashboard.
trans-unit.target: **User:** Enter the Deployment / FTP user that you copied from the dashboard.

trans-unit.source: This is the full FTP username, which has the form *webappname\username*.
trans-unit.target: This is the full FTP username, which has the form *webappname\username*.

trans-unit.source: **Password:** Enter the password that you specified when you set the deployment credentials.
trans-unit.target: **Password:** Enter the password that you specified when you set the deployment credentials.

trans-unit.source: On the **Transfer Settings** tab, select **Passive**.
trans-unit.target: On the **Transfer Settings** tab, select **Passive**.

trans-unit.source: Click **Connect**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Connect**.

trans-unit.source: If successful, FileZilla's console will display a `Status: Connected` message and issue a `LIST` command to list the directory contents.
trans-unit.target: If successful, FileZilla's console will display a `Status: Connected` message and issue a `LIST` command to list the directory contents.

trans-unit.source: In the **Local** site panel, select the source directory in which the JSPHello.war file resides; the path will be similar to the following:
trans-unit.target: In the **Local** site panel, select the source directory in which the JSPHello.war file resides; the path will be similar to the following:

trans-unit.source: In the **Remote** site panel, select the destination folder.
trans-unit.target: In the **Remote** site panel, select the destination folder.

trans-unit.source: You will deploy the WAR file to the `webapps` directory under the web app's root.
trans-unit.target: You will deploy the WAR file to the `webapps` directory under the web app's root.

trans-unit.source: Navigate to `/site/wwwroot`, right-click on `wwwroot`, and select **Create directory**.
trans-unit.target: Navigate to `/site/wwwroot`, right-click on `wwwroot`, and select **Create directory**.

trans-unit.source: Name the directory `webapps` and enter that directory.
trans-unit.target: Name the directory `webapps` and enter that directory.

trans-unit.source: Transfer JSPHello.war to `/site/wwwroot/webapps`.
trans-unit.target: Transfer JSPHello.war to `/site/wwwroot/webapps`.

trans-unit.source: Select JSPHello.war in the **Local** file list, right-click on it and select **Upload**.
trans-unit.target: Select JSPHello.war in the **Local** file list, right-click on it and select **Upload**.

trans-unit.source: You should see it appear in `/site/wwwroot/webapps`.
trans-unit.target: You should see it appear in `/site/wwwroot/webapps`.

trans-unit.source: After you copy JSPHello.war to the webapps directory, Tomcat Server will automatically unpack (unzip) the files in the WAR file.
trans-unit.target: After you copy JSPHello.war to the webapps directory, Tomcat Server will automatically unpack (unzip) the files in the WAR file.

trans-unit.source: Although Tomcat Server begins unpacking almost immediately, it might take a long time (possibly hours) for the files to appear in the FTP client.
trans-unit.target: Although Tomcat Server begins unpacking almost immediately, it might take a long time (possibly hours) for the files to appear in the FTP client.

trans-unit.source: Run the Hello World application on the Web App
trans-unit.target: Run the Hello World application on the Web App

trans-unit.source: After you have uploaded the WAR file and verified that Tomcat server has created an unpacked `JSPHello` directory, browse to `http://webdemowebapp.azurewebsites.net/JSPHello` to run the application.
trans-unit.target: After you have uploaded the WAR file and verified that Tomcat server has created an unpacked `JSPHello` directory, browse to `http://webdemowebapp.azurewebsites.net/JSPHello` to run the application.

trans-unit.source: **Note:** If you click **Browse** from the classic portal, you might
trans-unit.target: **Note:** If you click **Browse** from the classic portal, you might

trans-unit.source: get the default webpage, saying "This Java based web application has
trans-unit.target: get the default webpage, saying "This Java based web application has

trans-unit.source: been successfully created."
trans-unit.target: been successfully created."

trans-unit.source: You might have to refresh the webpage in
trans-unit.target: You might have to refresh the webpage in

trans-unit.source: order to view the application output instead of the default webpage.
trans-unit.target: order to view the application output instead of the default webpage.

trans-unit.source: When the application runs, you should see a web page with the following output:
trans-unit.target: When the application runs, you should see a web page with the following output:

trans-unit.source: Clean up Azure resources
trans-unit.target: Clean up Azure resources

trans-unit.source: This procedure creates an App Service web app.
trans-unit.target: This procedure creates an App Service web app.

trans-unit.source: You will be billed for the resource as long as it exists.
trans-unit.target: You will be billed for the resource as long as it exists.

trans-unit.source: Unless you plan to continue using the web app for testing or development, you should consider stopping or deleting it.
trans-unit.target: Unless you plan to continue using the web app for testing or development, you should consider stopping or deleting it.

trans-unit.source: A web app that has been stopped will still incur a small charge, but you can restart it at any time.
trans-unit.target: A web app that has been stopped will still incur a small charge, but you can restart it at any time.

trans-unit.source: Deleting a web app erases all data you have uploaded to it.
trans-unit.target: Deleting a web app erases all data you have uploaded to it.

trans-unit.source: test
trans-unit.target: test
